objtitle.title: A Female with a Horse’s Head, Perhaps Hippa

objdescid.compdate: c. 1790?The date is far from certain.

objinfo.medium: pencilThe pencil inscription, lower right, is the accession number written by a curator at the time the work was entered into the collection of the Fogg Art Museum.
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe pencil inscription, lower right, is the accession number written by a curator at the time the work was entered into the collection of the Fogg Art Museum.

provenance.name: Fogg Art Museum, Harvard University
provenance.note: Acquired at an unknown time, perhaps in the 1860s, by Horace Elisha Scudder (1838-1902); Mrs. Ingersoll Bowditch, deposited by her at the Fogg Art Museum in 1940; purchased by the Fogg Art Museum in 1967.

repository.addressline: Digital Imaging and Visual Resources Department:

desc.objtitle: *A Female with a Horse's Head, Perhaps Hippa*, object 1 (Butlin 88 verso)

objnote.p: The pencil inscription, lower right, is the accession number written by a curator at the time the work was entered into the collection of the Fogg Art Museum. For the water color drawing on the recto of this leaf, see *An Enthroned Old Man Offering Two Children to Heaven*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile, a female figure with a horse's head walks right in this drawing. With mouth open and long, flame-like hair or mane standing on end, she holds her bent right arm near the center of her chest and extends the left near her side. The fingers of both hands are spread. Although both legs are only visible above the knee, the figure appears to step forward with her right leg. She is likely nude, though some traces of a translucent gown may be visible near her buttocks and upper thighs. Butlin 88 suggests that this figure may be Hippa, an Egyptian goddess believed by Ovid and other classical authors to have been turned into a horse. A few rounded pencil lines right of the main figure might be a crouching figure with curly hair, facing left.

component.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile, a female figure with a horse's head stands or walks right in this drawing. With mouth open and long hair or mane and forelock standing on end, she holds her bent right arm near the center of her chest and extends the left near her side. The fingers of both hands are spread. Although both legs are only visible above the knee, the figure appears to step forward with her right leg. She is likely nude, though some traces of a translucent gown may be visible near her buttocks and upper thighs. Butlin 88 verso suggests that this figure may be Hippa, an Egyptian goddess believed by Ovid and other classical authors to have been turned into a horse.
A few rounded pencil lines right of the main figure might be a crouching figure with curly hair, facing left.
